Introduction

Alopecia (hair loss) can be classified as scarring or nonscarring based on the presence or absence of permanent hair follicle damage.  This article provides an overview of hair follicle cycling and discusses several common types of alopecia based on this classification.

Hair follicle cycling



Hair growth occurs in a cyclical pattern with 3 primary phases (

figure 1
):



  • The anagen phase is characterized by linear growth of the hair shaft associated with proliferation of hair follicle cells.  At any given time, 80%-90% of follicles are in the anagen phase, which lasts up to 5 years.
  • The catagen phase is the transition phase characterized by regression and apoptosis of follicular cells.  The hair shaft may continue to be extruded from the follicle but is no longer growing.  This phase lasts up to 2 weeks and typically accounts for <1% of follicles.
  • The telogen phase is the resting phase, with variable duration.  The hair shaft is shed during this phase in preparation for growth of a new hair.

Overview



Alopecia can be broadly divided (

figure 2
) into nonscarring and scarring alopecia:



  • Nonscarring alopecia is characterized by no or mild inflammation of the scalp or underlying skin (eg, eyebrows).  The hair follicle stem cells are preserved, thereby allowing for hair regrowth after hair loss.
  • Scarring (cicatricial) alopecia is characterized by significant inflammation in the scalp or underlying skin.  The hair follicle stem cells are destroyed by the inflammation and associated scarring, making hair loss permanent.


Alopecia may start as nonscarring and become scarring with repeated or continuous inflammation or insults (eg, trichotillomania, tinea capitis, and traction alopecia, which are discussed below).

Nonscarring alopecia



Hair loss in the following conditions is reversible.  However, if persistent or untreated, certain conditions (eg, traction alopecia, tinea capitis, and trichotillomania) may eventually lead to scarring alopecia that is irreversible.

Alopecia areata (AA)



  • Pathophysiology:  AA (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a T cellâ€“mediated attack on cells within the hair bulb at the base of the follicle that are responsible for keratin production and hair shaft elongation.  Affected follicles subsequently experience a premature shift from the growth phase (anagen) to the transition (catagen) and resting (telogen) phases, resulting in patchy hair shedding with preserved hair growth in unaffected areas.  Despite the autoimmune-mediated process, the hair follicle stem cells remain undamaged.  Therefore, hair regrowth is possible.
  • Clinical presentation:  Hair loss in AA has a relatively rapid onset and starts as patchy hair loss with well-defined borders (
    image 1
    ).  AA can progress to total scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis) or total body hair loss (alopecia universalis).  The underlying scalp or skin appears normal.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  Diagnosis is typically made clinically.  Close inspection (eg, using a dermatoscope) may show 3- to 4-mm hairs with narrowing of hair shafts close to the skin surface (exclamation point hairs), reflective of shaft weakening caused by bulb inflammation.  The hair pull test is often positive (ie, extraction of >5 strands when a cluster of ~50 hair fibers is pulled firmly).  When the diagnosis is unclear, a scalp biopsy is performed.  Due to AA's association with autoimmune thyroid disease, screening thyroid function studies are generally recommended.
  • Management:  Pharmacologic treatment of AA depends on the size of the lesions (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):
    • For limited lesions (eg, <50% of the scalp), intralesional corticosteroids (eg, triamcinolone) are preferred for adults.  Topical corticosteroids can be used as an alternative and are preferred in children.
    • For extensive (eg, >50% of the scalp) or refractory lesions, oral Janus kinase inhibitors (eg, baricitinib) or topical immunotherapy (eg, diphenylcyclopropenone, which stimulates hair regrowth) can be used
  • Complications/prognosis:  Even with treatment, AA has a variable course, with periods of relapse and spontaneous remission.  Hair loss often has psychosocial impacts on patients.

Telogen effluvium (TE)



  • Pathophysiology:  In TE (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ), follicles undergo a widespread shift into the rest/shedding (telogen) phase, with cessation of growth and subsequent shedding.  It is often triggered by a stressful event (eg, severe weight loss, pregnancy, major illness or surgery, psychiatric trauma), iron deficiency, or thyroid dysfunction.
  • Clinical presentation:  TE is characterized by diffuse hair thinning with normal underling scalp and hair shafts in light of a recent emotional or physical stressor.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  The diagnosis is usually made clinically with a hair pull test.  A limited laboratory evaluation, including complete blood count (and ferritin), TSH, and a serum chemistry panel, may be considered to identify endocrine and nutritional causes of TE if an acute stressor is not identified.
  • Management:  Psychological support for emotional trauma and treatment of underlying medical conditions (eg, hypothyroidism, iron deficiency), when present, are recommended.
  • Complications/prognosis:  TE is a self-limited disorder, provided underlying medical causes are treated, but may take up to a year to resolve completely.

Male and female pattern hair loss



Male pattern hair loss (MPHL) (androgenetic alopecia) and female pattern hair loss (FPHL) have variable presentations (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
):



  • Pathophysiology:  MPHL and FPHL are characterized by follicular miniaturization, which is when affected portions of the scalp have a shortened anagen (hair growth) phase, leading to shorter, thinner hair shafts with increased apoptosis at the dermal papillae.  The net result is the transformation of thick, terminal hairs into thin, vellus hairs, resulting in the appearance of decreased scalp hair coverage.

    • In men, follicular miniaturization is driven by genetics and effects of dihydrotestosterone (DHT).  In the affected scalp, there is increased local conversion of testosterone to DHT (by 5-alpha reductase) and increased concentrations of androgen receptors.  However, the total androgen levels are similar in affected and unaffected men.
    • In women, the cause of follicular miniaturization is uncertain.  Hair loss often occurs in women with hyperandrogenic states (eg, caused by polycystic ovary syndrome).  However, androgen levels in most women are normal.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • In men, hair loss is gradual and asymptomatic (
      figure 3
      ).  It typically involves the vertex, temporal scalp, or midfrontal regions with recession of the hairline (
      image 2
      ).  Signs may first appear during adolescence.
    • In women, gradual and asymptomatic hair loss occurs at the vertex or frontal scalp (
      image 3
      ).  Unlike MPHL, the hairline in FPHL is typically preserved.  FPHL can begin in childhood but is most common after menopause.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  MPHL and FPHL are diagnosed clinically based on the pattern of hair loss.  Examination finding of hair shafts of different calibers (due to follicular miniaturization) confirms the diagnosis.  Scalp biopsy is reserved for uncertain cases.  Given the association between FPHL and hyperandrogenic states, laboratory evaluation for hyperandrogenism is warranted only if findings (eg, hirsutism, irregular menstruation, infertility, severe acne) support a hyperandrogenic state.
  • Management:
    • MPHL:  First-line therapy is finasteride (a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor), which reduces the conversion of testosterone to DHT.  Topical minoxidil is an alternate agent and can be used concurrently with finasteride.  Through unclear mechanisms (possibly vasodilatory effects), minoxidil prolongs the follicular growth phase and reverses follicular miniaturization.
    • FPHL:  First-line therapy is topical minoxidil.  Through unclear mechanisms (possibly vasodilatory effects), it prolongs the follicular growth phase and reverses follicular miniaturization.
  • Complications/prognosis:  MPHL and FPHL progress over time, but only MPHL results in eventual baldness.

Traction alopecia (TA)



  • Pathophysiology:  Through unclear mechanisms, traction hairstyles (eg, ponytail, braids, buns, dreadlocks) may cause follicular inflammation that leads to follicular miniaturization, resulting in vellus-like hair (
    image 4
    ).  Hair loss is initially nonscarring, but prolonged traction causes irreversible hair loss due to permanent follicular damage (scarring alopecia).
  • Clinical presentation:  Initially, traction causes folliculitis that presents with follicular erythema and sterile pustules.  Persistent traction results in decreased hair density and, eventually, alopecia.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  The diagnosis is made clinically based on alopecia in a distribution consistent with a traction hairstyle.  A scalp biopsy may be obtained if the diagnosis is uncertain.
  • Management:
    • Cessation of traction hairstyles can aid in management.
    • Adjunctive therapies include minoxidil to enhance hair regrowth, as well as oral antibiotic (eg, doxycycline) and topical corticosteroid therapies when inflammation (eg, follicular erythema/pustules) is present.
    • For patients with scarring alopecia, hair transplantation and cosmetic camouflage (eg, wigs, scalp tattoos) can be considered.
  • Complications/prognosis:  TA of <1 year in duration is typically reversible with cessation of traction hairstyles.  In contrast, TA that has lasted several years is more likely to be permanent and unresponsive to medical therapy and hair style changes.

Tinea capitis (TC)



  • Pathophysiology:  TC (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ) is a dermatophyte infection most commonly caused by Trichophyton or Microsporum species.  The infection invades the hair follicles and hair shafts, causing hair breakage and alopecia.  It is spread via fomites (eg, comb, hat, pillowcase) or close contact with another individual with TC.
  • Clinical presentation:  TC typically occurs in children and patients who are immunocompromised.  Lesions consist of scaly, pruritic, erythematous plaques on the scalp associated with alopecia (
    image 5
    ).  Residual black dots representing broken hair shafts are often visible (
    image 6
    ).  Lesions expand centrifugally for weeks and are typically associated with tender cervical, occipital, or postauricular lymphadenopathy.  Rarely, a severe inflammatory reaction results in a kerion, which is a tender plaque with pustules, crusting, and drainage.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  Diagnosis is made clinically but can be confirmed with potassium hydroxide examination of the proximal hair shafts, which reveal fungal spores within or outside the hair shaft.
  • Management:  Systemic antifungal therapies (eg, oral griseofulvin or terbinafine) are required to treat TC due to poor penetrance of hair follicles with topical therapy.  Adjunctive treatments, such as ketoconazole shampoo, can be used to help prevent the spread of disease but are insufficient as monotherapy.
  • Complications/prognosis:  With timely systemic antifungal therapy, hair regrows as the infection clears.  However, severe cases (ie, if a kerion is present) with delayed treatment can result in scarring alopecia.

Trichotillomania



  • Pathophysiology:  This condition is characterized by compulsive hairpulling, often associated with anxiety or stress (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
    ).  Hairpulling may be an automatic behavior (without full awareness), or it may be preceded by tension and followed by relief.
  • Clinical presentation:  The condition typically occurs in children and adolescent girls and presents with irregular patches of hair loss showing hairs of different lengths (due to traumatic breakage at various points).  The underlying scalp/skin typically appears normal.  The scalp (
    image 7
    ), eye lashes, and eyebrows are commonly affected areas.  Total scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis) is atypical.
  • Evaluation/diagnosis:  Patients should undergo behavioral assessment.  The diagnosis is made based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders criteria.
  • Management:  Cognitive-behavioral therapy and habit reversal training are needed to help patients stop pulling hairs.  Selective serotonin inhibitors can be considered for severe or refractory cases.
  • Complications/prognosis:  Trichotillomania typically self-resolves within a year, although it can be lifelong.  Hair generally regrows with cessation of hairpulling.  However, with persistent and prolonged hairpulling, scarring alopecia may develop.  Patients who also ingest hair (trichophagia) may develop trichobezoars, which cause abdominal pain and bowel obstruction.


In addition to these conditions, syphilis (alopecia syphilitica, in which patients have patches of "moth-eaten" alopecia) and some congenital conditions can cause nonscarring alopecia.  The distribution of hair loss (focal, patterned, diffuse) can be a helpful clue when diagnosing a patient.  For example, focal hair loss can be seen in patients with AA and TA; a patterned distribution of hair loss can be seen in patients with MPHL, FPHL, TC, and trichotillomania; and diffuse hair loss can be seen in patients with TE.

Scarring (cicatricial) alopecia



Scarring (cicatricial) alopecia causes irreversible hair loss due to destruction of the hair follicles and stem cells from significant inflammation and associated scar tissue formation.  Cutaneous (discoid) lupus erythematosus is a classic example.  Other conditions are associated with primary (lymphocytic or neutrophilic) and secondary (eg, tinea capitis, trichotillomania) cicatricial alopecia.

Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE)



  • Pathophysiology:  DLE is an autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation of the skin and hair follicles that subsequently results in scar information.  DLE can occur in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and patients with DLE can go on to develop SLE.
  • Clinical presentation:  DLE typically affects African American and Hispanic women.  The rash is photosensitive and, therefore, most commonly presents on the face, neck, and arms, but it can also affect the scalp.  The primary lesions appear as mildly pruritic, scaly, red-to-violaceous patches/plaques that are round (discoid) in shape (
    image 8
    ).  Progressive inflammation leads to disappearance of hair follicle openings, scarring and hypopigmentation of the lesion's center, and hyperpigmentation of the lesion's periphery.  If lesions affect the scalp, scarring alopecia results (
    image 9
    ).
  • Evaluation:  Diagnosis is made clinically (eg, characteristic rash in a patient with SLE).  A biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis and distinguish SLE from other conditions with scaly and keratotic lesions (eg, psoriasis, lichen planus, eczema).  Serologic testing has limited diagnostic value because patients with isolated DLE (in the absence of SLE) usually have negative or low-titer antinuclear antibodies; these patients can test positive for anti-Ro antibodies (although this is rare).
  • Management:  Photoprotection, topical or intralesional corticosteroid therapy, or topical calcineurin inhibitor (eg, tacrolimus) are typically used initially.  Refractory lesions can be treated with antimalarial drugs (eg, hydroxychloroquine).
  • Complications/prognosis:  Skin and scalp lesions cause scarring, permanent hair loss, and dyspigmentation.  DLE can occur independently, but SLE eventually develops in up to 30% of the patients, with the risk highest in those with diffuse DLE skin lesions.

Summary



Alopecia can be nonscarring or scarring.  Hair loss in nonscarring alopecia is reversible, whereas hair loss in scarring alopecia is irreversible.  Common causes of nonscarring alopecia include alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and male and female pattern hair loss.  Traction alopecia, tinea capitis, and trichotillomania start as nonscarring alopecia but may progress to scarring alopecia if left untreated.  Discoid lupus erythematosus causes scarring alopecia.
